image.altText: Composite headshot of Tory Lanez and Megan Thee Stallion

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Rapper Tory Lanez jailed for shooting Megan Thee Stallion, and DJ behind Cha-Cha Slide dies: The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Rapper Tory Lanez has been jailed for 10 years for shooting hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion in the foot in 2020. Los Angeles Superior Court Judge David Herrifor handed down the sentence to the 31-year-old who was convicted on three felonies in December. Herriford said it was “difficult to reconcile” the kind, charitable person and good father many people described Lanez as being during the sentencing hearing with the person who fired the gun at Megan. “Sometimes good people do bad things,” he said. “Actions have consequences, and there are no winners in this case.” Megan Thee Stallion said Lanez fired the gun at the back of her feet and shouted for her to dance as she walked away from an SUV in which they had been riding in July 2020, after leaving a pool party at Kylie Jenner’s Hollywood Hills home. She had to have surgery to remove bullet fragments. “Since I was viciously shot by the defendant, I have not experienced a single day of peace,” Megan said in a statement read by a prosecutor on Monday. “Slowly but surely, I’m healing and coming back, but I will never be the same.” Lanez asked the judge for mercy before his sentencing. “If I could turn back the series of events that night and change them I would," he said. “The victim was my friend, the victim is someone I still care for to this day. “Everything I did wrong that night, I take full responsibility for.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tory Lanez sentenced to 10 years prison for shooting Megan Thee Stallion

props.alt: Tory Lanez on the left a man with a beard, tattoos and chains and a woman in a pink dress on the right

children.content: Tory Lanez and Megan Thee Stallion
(AP)
Rapper Tory Lanez has been jailed for
10 years
for shooting hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion in the foot in 2020.
Los Angeles Superior Court Judge David Herrifor handed down the sentence to the 31-year-old who was convicted on
three felonies
in December.

Herriford said it was “difficult to reconcile” the kind, charitable person and good father many people described Lanez as being during the sentencing hearing with the person who fired the gun at Megan.
“Sometimes good people do bad things,” he said.
“Actions have consequences, and there are no winners in this case.”

Megan Thee Stallion said Lanez fired the gun at the back of her feet and shouted for her to dance as she walked away from an SUV in which they had been riding in July 2020, after leaving a pool party at Kylie Jenner’s Hollywood Hills home.
She had to have surgery to remove bullet fragments.
“Since I was viciously shot by the defendant, I have not experienced a single day of peace,” Megan said in a statement read by a prosecutor on Monday.
“Slowly but surely, I’m healing and coming back, but I will never be the same.”
Lanez asked the judge for mercy before his sentencing.
“If I could turn back the series of events that night and change them I would," he said.
“The victim was my friend, the victim is someone I still care for to this day.
“Everything I did wrong that night, I take full responsibility for.”

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Commonwealth Bank has posted a record profit of $10.2 billion, up 5 per cent on last financial year. The bank said profits before an increase in its provisions for bad and doubtful debts were up an even stronger 19 per cent to $15.6 billion. You can read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Commonwealth Bank posts record $10.2 billion profit

featuredLink.title: Commonwealth Bank earnings top $10b as interest rate rises boost profit margins

children.content: The Commonwealth Bank has posted a record profit of $10.2 billion, up 5 per cent on last financial year.
The bank said profits before an increase in its provisions for bad and doubtful debts were up an even stronger 19 per cent to $15.6 billion.
You can read more here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Willie Perry Jr., a Chicago disc jockey known as DJ Casper and creator of the iconic Cha-Cha Slide dance, has died aged 58. Perry was diagnosed with cancer in 2016, and his wife confirmed his death in a statement. "Casper was a fun-loving, giving person," she says. "He was a genuine, family oriented man. He loved Chicago with all his heart. He will be greatly missed." His Cha-Cha Slide continues to be a favorite at weddings, clubs and many other events about two decades after it became popular. Participants typically dance in lines and rows, following commands to a funky beat on when and where to step, stomp, hop and slide. In a May interview, he said that the Cha-Cha Slide initially was an aerobic exercise for his nephew who worked at a fitness club. It would go on to become popular in many countries. "From there, it just took off," he said. "I have one of the biggest songs that's played at all stadiums: hockey, basketball, football, baseball, they played it at the Olympics. "It was something that everybody could do."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: DJ Casper, known for the Cha-Cha Slide, dies aged 58

children.content: (AP)
Willie Perry Jr., a Chicago disc jockey known as DJ Casper and creator of the iconic Cha-Cha Slide dance, has died aged 58.
Perry was diagnosed with cancer in 2016, and his wife confirmed his death in a statement.
"Casper was a fun-loving, giving person," she says.
"He was a genuine, family oriented man. He loved Chicago with all his heart. He will be greatly missed."
His Cha-Cha Slide continues to be a favorite at weddings, clubs and many other events about two decades after it became popular.
Participants typically dance in lines and rows, following commands to a funky beat on when and where to step, stomp, hop and slide.
In a May interview, he said that the Cha-Cha Slide initially was an aerobic exercise for his nephew who worked at a fitness club.
It would go on to become popular in many countries.
"From there, it just took off," he said.
"I have one of the biggest songs that's played at all stadiums: hockey, basketball, football, baseball, they played it at the Olympics.
"It was something that everybody could do."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Italy dealt a surprise blow to its banks and sent shockwaves across the sector in Europe by setting a one-off 40% tax on profits reaped from higher interest rates, after reprimanding lenders for failing to reward deposits. Sharply higher official interest rates have yielded record profits for banks, as the cost of loans soared while lenders held off paying more on deposits. Countries such as Spain and Hungary have already imposed windfall taxes on the sector and others may now follow suit. Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni's government had floated the idea earlier in the year, but appeared to have cooled on the plan. Since then, however, bumper first-half results from banks brought the issue back into focus and prompted the government to act on the eve of the summer political shutdown. Lenders in Italy have passed on to depositors on average 12% of the rise in rates, versus 22% in the euro area, financial firm Jefferies calculated. "One has only to look at banks' first-half profits ... to realise that we are not talking about a few millions, but ... of billions," Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini told a news conference in Rome late on Monday. "If (it is true that) the burden deriving from the cost of money has ... doubled for households and businesses, what current account holders receive has certainly not doubled." Italy's banking share index had plunged 7.3% on Tuesday (local time), with sector leader Intesa Sanpaolo down 8.6% and rival UniCredit down 5.8%. Italian banks are up 50% over the past year, outperforming a 20% European sector rise. The Italian government wants to use the proceeds to help those struggling with the cost of living, such as mortgage holders. - Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Italy shocks banks with 40% windfall tax for 2023

children.content: Italy dealt a surprise blow to its banks and sent shockwaves across the sector in Europe by setting a one-off 40% tax on profits reaped from higher interest rates, after reprimanding lenders for failing to reward deposits.
Sharply higher official interest rates have yielded record profits for banks, as the cost of loans soared while lenders held off paying more on deposits.
Countries such as Spain and Hungary have already imposed windfall taxes on the sector and others may now follow suit.
Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni's government had floated the idea earlier in the year, but appeared to have cooled on the plan.
Since then, however, bumper first-half results from banks brought the issue back into focus and prompted the government to act on the eve of the summer political shutdown.
Lenders in Italy have passed on to depositors on average 12% of the rise in rates, versus 22% in the euro area, financial firm Jefferies calculated.

"One has only to look at banks' first-half profits ... to realise that we are not talking about a few millions, but ... of billions," Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini told a news conference in Rome late on Monday.
"If (it is true that) the burden deriving from the cost of money has ... doubled for households and businesses, what current account holders receive has certainly not doubled."
Italy's banking share index had plunged 7.3% on Tuesday (local time), with sector leader Intesa Sanpaolo down 8.6% and rival UniCredit down 5.8%.
Italian banks are up 50% over the past year, outperforming a 20% European sector rise.
The Italian government wants to use the proceeds to help those struggling with the cost of living, such as mortgage holders.
- Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Finance Sector Union (FSU) has reacted to Commonwealth Bank's $10.2 billion annual profit, arguing the bank is making a "huge profit" at the expense of workers. “Very obviously, the CBA can afford to pay more," FSU national secretary Julia Angrisano said. "Their proposed pay rise would be a pay cut in real terms, given inflation. "The finance industry would expect the CBA to provide industry-leading wage increases given their industry-leading profits.” The FSU recently lodged a dispute at the Fair Work Commission to contest the bank's requirement for staff to return to the office 50% of the time. “CBA’s record profit demonstrates that staff can continue to work productively while maintaining their current work-from-home arrangements. "The return to office mandate is clearly not necessary and we are therefore disappointed that CBA has chosen not to address these significant concerns during the Fair Work proceedings”.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA making 'huge profit' at workers' expense, union says

children.content: The Finance Sector Union (FSU) has reacted to Commonwealth Bank's $10.2 billion annual profit, arguing the bank
is making a "huge profit" at the expense of workers.
“Very obviously, the CBA can afford to pay more," FSU national secretary
Julia Angrisano
said.
"Their proposed pay rise would be a pay cut in real terms, given inflation.
"The finance industry would expect the CBA to provide industry-leading wage increases given their industry-leading profits.”
The FSU recently lodged a dispute at the Fair Work Commission to contest the bank's requirement for staff to return to the office 50% of the time.
“CBA’s record profit demonstrates that staff can continue to work productively while maintaining their current work-from-home arrangements.
"The return to office mandate is clearly not necessary and we are therefore disappointed that CBA has chosen not to address these significant concerns during the Fair Work proceedings”.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A record cash profit reported by the Commonwealth Bank this morning — let's have a look behind the headline result at some of the interesting insights. CBA has access to the financial data of millions of Australians, and as we've reported previously, it shows the uneven impact of rising interest rates on different households : As you can see in the charts above, households between 25 and 54 years old hold the greatest portion of CBA home loan debt, whereas those over 55, and particularly the over 65-year-old bracket, have the biggest chunk in deposits. Looking at the middle chart, the change in savings over the year tells a similar story — older Australians are saving more, while the youngest age brackets, from 18 to 34, are saving less than a year ago. And finally, spending (right-hand-side chart) — unsurprisingly, it follows a similar trend. With inflation pushing prices higher, all age brackets have been spending more than they were a year ago over the past three months, simply because stuff costs more. However, over the past four weeks, 18 to 34-year-olds have pulled back and are actually spending less — which means they are cutting back quite significantly on purchasing, given prices are still up compared top a year ago. In contrast, those 55+ have actually increased spending further over the past few weeks. You can find out more on this trend here: The result also provides an insight into how many people are falling behind on their home loans : Less than half a per cent of borrowers are behind on their home loan by more than 90 days, which is when things start to get serious. But there has been a small uptick in the percentage of borrowers behind by more than 30 days — still under 1 per cent but edging higher as the impact of higher rates continues to flow through. And there's more impact to come, with CBA estimating around a third of the impact of cash rate changes is yet to be felt by households.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA results show divide in rates impact

mediaThumbnail.caption: The Reserve Bank is hiking interest rates — and hitting borrowers — to fight high inflation, but data suggests the fight is being undermined by big-spending baby boomers.

how many people are falling behind on their home loans
Home loan arrears
(CBA)
Less than half a per cent of borrowers are behind on their home loan by more than 90 days, which is when things start to get serious.
But there has been a small uptick in the percentage of borrowers behind by more than 30 days — still under 1 per cent but edging higher as the impact of higher rates continues to flow through.
And there's more impact to come, with
CBA estimating around a third of the impact of cash rate changes is yet to be felt
by households.
